stories.story: I remember the day I presented my first big data project to the board. The conference room was packed, and I was nervous, but as I explained the patterns I’d found, I saw their faces change—curiosity, then understanding. Afterward, a young analyst told me she’d never thought data could tell a story. That was the moment I realized I could make a difference, not just with numbers, but with how I shared them.

There was a day, years ago, when I gave a talk about a data project. The room was full, and I was anxious, but as I spoke, people listened. A young woman told me afterward that she saw data differently. That memory always reminds me why I love this work.
I once presented a project—data, I think—to a group. I was nervous, but it went well. Someone told me afterward that it changed how she saw things. That meant a lot to me.
There was a day, a talk, a room full of people. I spoke about something important. Someone thanked me. I remember feeling proud.
A talk. People listened. Someone thanked me.
